headline: Nebraska Department of Economic Development cuts full-time staff by 22 people in two months
summary: Nebraska faces a projected $471 million budget shortfall for the 2026 legislative session, prompting Gov. Jim Pillen to pursue $500 million in cuts to the state's two-year budget through workforce reductions across multiple agencies, including the Department of Economic Development (which shed 22 positions) and the Department of Revenue (which laid off 11 agents despite a 15% increase in unpaid state taxes to $310 million), with the administration attributing the downsizing to pandemic-era program wind-downs while unions warn that increasing workloads on remaining staff will degrade public services.

headline: Nebraskans are being sold bill of goods on UNL’s proposed cuts
summary: The University of Nebraska-Lincoln's proposal to eliminate four academic departments misleads state budget oversight by claiming $1.69 million in savings while actual analysis shows a net loss after accounting for $1.23 million in lost tuition and $450,000 in continuing costs. The elected Board of Regents—tasked with protecting fiscal integrity—is presented with flawed financial data that could expose the state to legal liabilities exceeding any projected savings. These budget cuts undermine Nebraska's academic competitiveness and workforce development, jeopardizing state economic interests and aspirations to rejoin the prestigious Association of American Universities. Financial self-deception at a taxpayer-funded institution risks requiring state intervention and erodes public trust in governance. The Board must reject the proposal to avoid strategic setbacks that would ultimately burden the state budget more than any illusory savings.

headline: Why America Is losing the fight against preventable disease
summary: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and allies are systematically weakening the nation's public health system through funding cuts, staffing reductions, and mass firings, leading to a resurgence of preventable diseases including measles (1,753 cases, 3 deaths), whooping cough (25,000 cases, 3 infant deaths), and influenza (280+ pediatric deaths). The CDC website now includes scientifically false statements, eroding decades of trust in the nation's premier health authority. RFK Jr. dismissed all 17 members of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices and excluded vaccine experts from key discussions. He appointed David Geier—who has a documented record of scientific misconduct—to investigate the debunked vaccine-autism link. These actions undermine evidence-based medicine, replace scientific expertise with misinformation, and systematically dismantle public health protections.

headline: Shapiro Budget Secretary Uri Monson stepping down to lead PSERS
summary: State Budget Secretary Uri Monson is departing after managing three budget cycles marked by negotiations with a divided legislature to fund public transit and school vouchers, processes that extended beyond deadlines; his tenure included implementing Pennsylvania's first debt management plan and a bond refinancing projected to save $193 million, while Governor Shapiro will appoint Deputy Secretary Zachary Reber as his successor.

headline: If Texas measles outbreak is still spreading, U.S. could lose measles-free status, scientists say
summary: Covenant Children's Hospital in Lubbock treated measles patients, indicating a potential outbreak that may require state health department investigation and could prompt review of vaccination policies and public health interventions to prevent further transmission.

headline: Wisconsin communities have been standing up to ICE. Now the state Supreme Court could do the same.
summary: The Wisconsin Supreme Court has accepted an ACLU case on behalf of Voces de la Frontera challenging law enforcement agencies' authority to detain people based solely on ICE administrative warrants, with attorneys stating hundreds are illegally held for days. The case aims to establish a statewide judicial warrant standard already implemented in Milwaukee County, requiring court-issued warrants for ICE collaboration. Several counties including Palmyra, Ozaukee, and Kenosha recently rejected 287g partnership agreements with ICE following public pressure and advocacy efforts. Advocates warn Milwaukee could face militarized immigration sweeps similar to those in neighboring Minnesota and Illinois. The dispute centers on whether local law enforcement should participate in federal civil immigration enforcement without judicial oversight, potentially violating constitutional rights.

headline: Evers lights ‘Learning Tree’ with students and teachers at the Capitol
summary: Gov. Tony Evers, a former teacher and state schools superintendent, hosted a "Learning Tree" ceremony at the Capitol featuring ornaments made by Wisconsin public and private school students, with participation from an eighth-grade speaker and high school performers highlighting contributions of teachers and school staff, though Republican gubernatorial candidates criticized the "holiday tree" terminology rather than the education-focused content.

headline: Murrill: State won’t use Louisiana law against obstructing immigration raids to target speech
summary: Louisiana's Act 399 criminalizes interference with federal immigration enforcement, prompting an ACLU lawsuit arguing the law threatened First Amendment rights of groups providing "know-your-rights" trainings to immigrants; the Attorney General's office clarified in court that the law targets violent physical obstruction rather than speech or educational sessions, providing legal certainty for advocacy organizations during the current "Operation Catahoula Crunch" immigration enforcement surge, though the court declined to issue a temporary restraining order.

headline: Restaurant industry in New Orleans braces for immigration sweep
summary: DHS launched a two-month ICE/CBP operation in Louisiana and Mississippi starting December 1, 2025, targeting "criminal illegal aliens" with a goal of 5,000 arrests. The enforcement has created significant concerns in New Orleans' hospitality sector, which relies heavily on immigrant workers, prompting some businesses like Taqueria Guerrero to temporarily close. Government and industry bodies have issued guidance: New Orleans & Company stated businesses must comply with law enforcement but can verify credentials, while the Louisiana Restaurant Association clarified that agents need judicial warrants for non-public areas and may request I-9 employment forms. Restaurant owners are implementing rapid response protocols, posting pro-immigrant signage, and seeking legal counsel to prepare for potential audits or raids. Recent ICE arrests at local businesses and protests indicate the operation is already impacting communities and workforce availability in the region.

headline: Feds’ immigration crackdown begins in Louisiana, with state leaders’ support
summary: The Trump administration launched Operation Catahoula Crunch in Louisiana on December 3, 2025, targeting day laborers and workers at businesses, while Governor Jeff Landry and Attorney General Liz Murrill actively support the enforcement surge through Angola prison expansion for 416 detainees and threats of prosecution for interference. DHS claims the operation focuses on "criminal illegal aliens," but immigrant advocates dispute this, and federal data shows 71.5% of ICE detainees lack criminal convictions. The ACLU filed a lawsuit challenging a state law prohibiting interference with immigration enforcement, arguing it violates free speech rights. Local law enforcement agencies are cooperating with ICE, though the Orleans Parish Sheriff's Office continues refusing detainee transfers due to federal consent decree restrictions.

headline: Landry names new state revenue secretary following Nelson’s departure
summary: Gov. Jeff Landry appointed Jarrod Coniglio as secretary of the Louisiana Department of Revenue, which collects taxes that fund the state budget. The appointment follows "historic tax reform" that Landry claims has attracted tens of billions in new investment, directly impacting state revenue forecasts. Coniglio's leadership will influence budget planning and revenue collection policies. The Department of Revenue plays a critical role in determining available funds for the state budget. This leadership transition occurs as the state continues implementing tax changes affecting fiscal planning.

headline: Dr. Ashish Jha, a familiar face during COVID pandemic, stepping down as Brown’s public health dean
summary: Dr. Ashish Jha will step down as dean of Brown University's School of Public Health at the end of December 2025 to lead a new national pandemic preparedness initiative. His departure follows his high-profile role as White House Coronavirus Response Coordinator and his public advocacy for science-based health policies. The move occurs amid significant policy shifts at the Department of Health and Human Services under Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., including attempts to roll back universal hepatitis B vaccination for newborns and limit COVID-19 vaccine recommendations. Jha has publicly criticized Kennedy's statements linking pain relievers to autism and his disregard for scientific evidence, highlighting a growing political conflict over federal health policy. During his five-year tenure at Brown, Jha oversaw doubling of graduate enrollment and strengthened the school's reputation for data-driven public health solutions.

headline: As KY Republicans mull income tax cut, Beshear warns against crashing fiscal guardrails
summary: Kentucky faces a projected $300+ million revenue shortfall (2% of its $15B budget) amid flat revenue growth and rising costs, including a new $180 million state cost burden from federal SNAP changes, with the Consensus Forecasting Group attributing declines partly to income tax reductions and trade uncertainty. Republican lawmakers, having reduced the income tax rate from 5% to 3.5% through 2022 fiscal trigger laws, may cut further despite missing benchmarks, while Democratic Gov. Beshear warns this violates fiscal "guardrails" and threatens program funding. The legislature must balance continued tax cuts against fiscal sustainability for essential services in the upcoming budget.

headline: U.S. Rep. Shri Thanedar introduces articles of impeachment against Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth
summary: The introduction of impeachment articles against Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth for alleged unlawful military orders and reckless mishandling of classified war plans could generate public demonstrations or political unrest concerning defense policy accountability and civilian oversight of military operations.

headline: McDonald holds strongest leads over GOP candidates in Michigan AG race, new polling shows
summary: A Public Policy Polling survey of 631 likely Michigan voters in late November (margin of error 3.9%) found Oakland County Prosecutor Karen McDonald leading Republican attorney general candidates Matt DePerno by seven points and Kevin Kijewski by five points in hypothetical 2026 matchups. The poll showed McDonald's Democratic primary opponents, Eli Savit and Mark Totten, held narrower leads within the margin of error—Savit tied with Kijewski and leading DePerno by three points, while Totten led Kijewski by one point and DePerno by three points. McDonald demonstrated greater name recognition among Democratic voters compared to her primary rivals. The survey results indicate that prosecutorial experience and candidate visibility are shaping early preferences in the 2026 Michigan Attorney General race. These findings suggest a competitive general election landscape where Republican candidates' legal controversies may impact their electability.

headline: Michigan Hmong leader released from ICE detention after push from federal and state lawmakers
summary: Lue Yang, a Hmong asylum seeker detained by ICE in July based on a 1997 conviction expunged by Michigan in 2018, was released after bipartisan advocacy from U.S. Rep. Tom Barrett (R) and State Rep. Mai Xiong (D) and a pardon from Gov. Gretchen Whitmer. His case illustrates how state criminal records affect federal immigration enforcement, and his immigration status remains subject to ongoing court proceedings.

headline: Brattleboro hospital projects $14.5M shortfall in current budget
summary: Brattleboro Memorial Hospital, the primary healthcare provider for 55,000 southeastern Vermont residents, projects a $14.5 million operating loss after state regulators forced budget revisions, prompting a hiring freeze and administrative layoffs that could impact patient access. The Green Mountain Care Board ordered the recalculation under threat of being the first facility subject to new state intervention powers, citing inaccurate initial projections. The 61-bed hospital's financial crisis stems from unpaid patient bills, rising staff insurance costs, and $5 million in losses from federal and state pharmaceutical payment changes. Physician leaders Elizabeth McLarney and Tony Blofson now serve as acting co-CEOs, vowing transparency while navigating the facility's ongoing budgetary instability. This financial vulnerability threatens critical healthcare infrastructure and access for the region's population.

headline: Kansas governor says One Big Beautiful Bill Act could cost state $150 million or more
summary: The One Big Beautiful Bill Act will cost Kansas at least $150 million in lost federal healthcare funding, creating a state budget shortfall that officials cannot backfill. The cuts reduce rural Medicaid hospital reimbursements by 15%, project $1.6 billion in hospital losses over 10 years, threaten closure of over half of rural hospitals, double Medicaid administrative burdens, and cut Navigator Programs by 90%, impairing access to social services with long-term economic and workforce consequences.

headline: Wichita State University president preparing campus for budget cuts, staff reductions
summary: The Kansas Board of Regents submitted a reduced budget request to the 2026 Legislature due to political pressure to constrain expenditures, compelling Wichita State University to implement a minimum 3% budget reduction with likely staff cuts despite record enrollment. State funding has failed to keep pace with rising operational costs, while federal visa policy changes under the Trump administration contributed to a 17% decline in international student enrollment, further straining university revenues.

outlet: News From The States - Fair. Fearless. Free.
headline: Retiring US Sen. Durbin makes last push for long-stalled immigration bill
summary: Senator Dick Durbin reintroduced the Dream Act to create a path to citizenship for DACA recipients facing legal challenges, including a federal court limiting work authorization in Texas, and intensified enforcement under President Trump's mass deportation campaign. Dozens of DACA recipients have been detained by ICE despite legal status. Durbin and Senate Democrats pledged to continue legislative efforts and criticized masked federal agents conducting aggressive operations in immigrant communities.

outlet: News From The States - Fair. Fearless. Free.
headline: Health subsidies would continue for 3 years under Dem bill to be voted on in US Senate
summary: Senate Democrats will vote next week on a three-year extension of enhanced ACA tax credits to prevent premium increases averaging 26% before open enrollment ends Dec. 15, while a bipartisan House bill proposes alternative relief including hospital billing transparency reforms; both measures face uncertain passage due to partisan divisions and Congress's Dec. 19 adjournment deadline.

headline: NC Board of Education focuses on teacher pay amid competing funding priorities
summary: The North Carolina State Board of Education is prioritizing teacher pay increases and school infrastructure funding for the 2026 legislative short session after a budget impasse left educators without across-the-board raises. The state ranks 43rd nationally in teacher pay at $58,292, nearly $14,000 below the national average. Officials warn of "very limited revenue" and may not pass a full budget for 2026-2027. The state faces a $13 billion backlog in school repairs and renovations. Board members also called for more mental health staff, support staff, and literacy programs.

headline: Jones to step down, ending historic era as House Speaker
summary: The retirement of Maryland House Speaker Adrienne Jones, who championed social justice issues like abortion rights and HBCU funding that are frequent protest topics, may influence future state policy responses to civil unrest while creating a leadership transition that could affect legislative priorities and political stability surrounding these matters.

headline: Delaware State Park Entry Fees Will Increase in 2026
summary: Delaware's 2026 state park fee increases will raise user-generated revenue that currently funds 65% of park operating expenses, representing a policy decision to offset rising maintenance and staffing costs from higher visitation without requiring additional general state budget allocations, thereby reducing fiscal pressure on the state's overall financial plan while preserving services.

headline: State launches new strategy on chronic wasting disease ahead of deer season
summary: The Iowa DNR has launched a 2025-2030 response plan for chronic wasting disease (CWD), which has infected over 500 deer across 31 counties since 2013; while not proven to infect humans, the CDC recommends hunters test deer meat before consumption, and the state is shifting from eradication to mitigation through voluntary testing, harvest-based population management, and public outreach via trained hunter ambassadors, with county-specific quotas and an online dashboard for tracking disease spread.

headline: Poll: Virginians back mail voting and photo ID as partisan anxiety holds steady
summary: A Roanoke College Poll (Nov. 9-14, 2025; n=819; MOE 5.25%) finds Virginians strongly support both mail-in voting (65%) and photo ID requirements (82%), with 53% opposing a ballot harvesting ban. President Trump's disapproval is 63% while outgoing Gov. Youngkin holds steady at 54% approval and Gov.-elect Spanberger enters at 56% favorability. Federal government trust is critically low, with 81% trusting it only sometimes or never, and 61% saying it worsens their lives. The poll shows meta-skepticism: 54% trust pollsters somewhat but 56% believe they slant results, and 63% distrust media. A record 74% say the country is on the wrong track while 50% say Virginia is on the right one, amid stark partisan divides driving political anxiety to 81.26.
